course_title: Communication and Feeding Skills in Children II

learning_outcomes.description: Collaborate with families and significant others to develop relevant communication and/or feeding goals for children under five years of age (Speech Pathology Australia Professional Standards, Domains/Standards 1.4, 1.6, 1.7, 2.5, 3.1 and 3.4)

Plan and implement holistic and evidence-based intervention for communication and/or feeding difficulties experienced by children under five years of age. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5, 1.6, 2.5, 2.6, 3.1, 3.4 and 3.5)

Demonstrate critical reflection and clinical reasoning in providing person- and family-centred services to children under five years of age and their significant others. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.4, 1.6, 2.2, 2.5, 3.3 and 3.5)

Explain how to uphold the Code of Ethics when managing children under five years of age with communication and/or feeding difficulties and their families. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, and 1.5)

Develop a culturally responsive intervention plan for children under five years of age who are from an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander background and their families. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.3, 1.4, 1.5, 1.6, 1.7, 2.1, 2.5, 2.6, 3.1, 3.3 and 3.4)
Analyse the role of interprofessional teams in the overall management of communication and feeding difficulties in children under five years of age. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.4, 1.7, 2.6 and 3.4)

Demonstrate the ability to work effectively in an interprofessional team, alongside speech pathology and social work colleagues, towards a common goal. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.4, 1.5, 2.5, 2.6, 3.1 and 3.4)

Recognise and reflect on interprofessional practice skills including role clarification, team functioning, interprofessional communication, and client-centred care (SPA PS Domains/Standards – 1.4, 1.5, 2.2, 2.5, 2.6, 3.1 and 3.4).

assessments.task_description:
Inter Professional Collaborative Practice (IPCP) Curriculum Assessment

The assessment will be completed in the tutorial class on 25th July or 1 August 2025, with a final submission date set a week later.

This is a team assessment, and all team members are expected to contribute equally to the team’s assessment items during the tutorial. Teams will be assigned prior to the tutorial.

There are two (2) parts to this assessment both based upon a client video that your team will choose during the tutorial class.

  1. Part One requires you to complete a worksheet and will draw on the online and face-to-face content of the GEMS IPCP module one, focusing on role-clarification and client-centred care. Length: There is no word limit for the worksheet (Part One)
  2.  Part Two requires you to complete a table and will draw on the on the online and face-to-face content of the GEMS IPCP module one, focusing on interprofessional communication, team functioning and client-centred care. Length: There is no word limit for the table (Part Two).


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Teams will need to submit both assessment pieces in the Assessment tab on the IPCP Learn.UQ course site at the end of the tutorial class.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
Component 1 due 22/08/2025 1:00 pm

Component 2 due 19/09/2025 1:00 pm

Component 3 due 13/10/2025 1:00 pm
assessments.task_description:
This is an authentic assessment that allows you to bring together the theory from week 1 to week 8 and to integrate and apply it to a case. You will be provided with case information and case data for a young child (0-5 years) presenting with communication difficulties. You will be required to (a) identify goals that are a priority for this case; (b) develop a holistic intervention plan with a clear rationale; and (c) develop an individualised session plan, with a focus on evidence-based practice, person and family-centred care approaches and alignment with the Professional Standards for Speech Pathologists in Australia (2020) and the Speech Pathology Australia Code of Ethics (2020).


This assessment includes three (3) different components:


Component 1: Goal setting Interprofessional

  • Due date: Week 4
  • Weight: 5%
  • Description: Students will have to identify goals that are a priority for the case.
  • Submission: Component 1 is to be submitted via the course eLearning Blackboard site. An SHRS coversheet signed by the student must accompany the submission.


Component 2: Intervention Planning

  • Due date: Week 8
  • Weight: 10%
  • Description: Students will have to develop a holistic intervention plan with a clear rationale.
  • Submission: Component 2 is to be submitted via the course eLearning Blackboard site. An SHRS coversheet signed by the student must accompany the submission.


Component 3: Session planning

  • Due date: Week 11
  • Weight: 20%
  • Description: Students will create an individualised, evidence-based, and family-centred session plan for the case.
  • Submission: The case-based component is to be submitted via the course eLearning Blackboard site. An SHRS coversheet signed by the student must accompany the submission.


A detailed task description and marking criteria will be made available on the course Blackboard site.


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assessment task is to be submitted via the course elearning Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Paediatric Feeding Experience - Progress note writing
assessments.task_description:
Students will participate in a 2-hour practical session focused on paediatric feeding, designed to support the development of skills in managing paediatric dysphagia. During the session, they will complete a series of part tasks (e.g., infant oral reflex examination, positioning, cue reading, and use of feeding equipment) and engage in a simulated interaction with the caregiver of a child experiencing feeding difficulties. In the simulation, students will conduct the session, make appropriate recommendations, and develop a management plan. After the practical, students will submit a clinical progress note based on the session.


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assessment task is to be submitted via the course elearning Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This is an authentic assessment that allows you to demonstrate person- and family-centred practice in the context of an intervention session for a young child with communication difficulties. Students will be provided with case information on a young child with fluency difficulties.

Individually, each student will complete two components:

  1. Session Plan: Each student will write a session plan for the child targeting relevant intervention goals
  2. Intervention Video (6 minutes): Using clinical reasoning and evidence-based practice, each student will create a video:
  • Summarising the child's progress throughout the intervention, and
  • Demonstrating the implementation of a family-centred and evidence-based intervention approach tailored to the child's needs.


A detailed task description and marking criteria will be made available on the course Blackboard site.


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assessment task is to be submitted via the course e-learning Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This exam will be delivered in Inspera Assessment and will be completed on your personal laptop on campus.

This examination provides the opportunity to reflect on and synthesise the knowledge and skills developed across the whole semester and apply this knowledge to authentic cases. Integration of knowledge and skills includes content gained from lectures, tutorials and workshops and other relevant learning activities in the course. Further information, including details of the format of the exam, and permitted materials will be provided on the SPCH7121 Blackboard site in the second half of semester.


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom O-week To Week 1(21 Jul - 03 Aug)
learning_activities.topic:
GEMS Interprofessional Collaborative Practice Module

GEMS Interprofessional Collaborative Practice Module (Friday 25th July 2025 or Friday 1st August 2025)

1 x Tutorial – 3 hours

You will work in small teams in the tutorial with students from: Audiology, Dentistry, Dietetics, Nursing, Occupational Therapy, Physiotherapy, Psychology, Social Work and Speech Pathology. There is one module consisting of on-line preparation and a face-to-face tutorial class. You will work in your small team to engage in a range of learning activities to develop your knowledge and skills to help prepare you for working in interprofessional collaborative teams when caring for clients. 


Learning outcomes: L08
learning_activities.topic_description: GEMS Interprofessional Collaborative Practice Module GEMS Interprofessional Collaborative Practice Module (Friday 25th July 2025 or Friday 1st August 2025) 1 x Tutorial – 3 hours You will work in small teams in the tutorial with students from: Audiology, Dentistry, Dietetics, Nursing, Occupational Therapy, Physiotherapy, Psychology, Social Work and Speech Pathology. There is one module consisting of on-line preparation and a face-to-face tutorial class. You will work in your small team to engage in a range of learning activities to develop your knowledge and skills to help prepare you for working in interprofessional collaborative teams when caring for clients.

learning_activities.topic:
Introductory lecture

The introductory lecture will provide an overview of speech pathology management of communication and feeding/mealtime difficulties in young children. Due to timetabling difficulties, lecture one will be pre-recorded and released to students ahead of the Week 1 tutorial.
learning_activities.topic_description: Introductory lecture The introductory lecture will provide an overview of speech pathology management of communication and feeding/mealtime difficulties in young children. Due to timetabling difficulties, lecture one will be pre-recorded and released to students ahead of the Week 1 tutorial.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 12(28 Jul - 26 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Online self-directed learning modules (self-directed learning)

A series of weekly online lectures will provide information on the holistic management of communication and feeding/mealtime difficulties in children under five years of age. The self-directed learning module content will cover a broad range of topics, including family-centred care and cultural capability frameworks, goal-setting, prevention and promotion of communication difficulties in young children, neurodiversity and neurodivergence, and the management of predominant difficulties observed in children under five years of age (e.g., language, literacy, speech, voice, fluency, and feeding).
learning_activities.topic_description: Online self-directed learning modules (self-directed learning) A series of weekly online lectures will provide information on the holistic management of communication and feeding/mealtime difficulties in children under five years of age. The self-directed learning module content will cover a broad range of topics, including family-centred care and cultural capability frameworks, goal-setting, prevention and promotion of communication difficulties in young children, neurodiversity and neurodivergence, and the management of predominant difficulties observed in children under five years of age (e.g., language, literacy, speech, voice, fluency, and feeding).

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 12(28 Jul - 26 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Weekly on campus tutorials

Tutorials will be conducted from weeks 1-8, 10 and week 12 of semester and will incorporate inquiry-based learning and small group discussion to further explore early speech pathology approaches to the management of communication and feeding/mealtime difficulties in children under five years of age. Tutorials have been designed for experiential learning and therefore, students are expected to attend and participate in all tutorials. It is essential that students prepare for tutorials by completing the online self-paced learning modules and associated preparation activities. As students will be working in small groups during this learning activity, tutorials will not be recorded.
learning_activities.topic_description: Weekly on campus tutorials Tutorials will be conducted from weeks 1-8, 10 and week 12 of semester and will incorporate inquiry-based learning and small group discussion to further explore early speech pathology approaches to the management of communication and feeding/mealtime difficulties in children under five years of age. Tutorials have been designed for experiential learning and therefore, students are expected to attend and participate in all tutorials. It is essential that students prepare for tutorials by completing the online self-paced learning modules and associated preparation activities. As students will be working in small groups during this learning activity, tutorials will not be recorded.

learning_activities.topic:
Interprofessional workshop

Students will participate in one (1) interprofessional workshop with Social Work students. This workshop will be held on campus and will not be recorded. Attendance is highly encouraged as Component 3 in the Holistic Assessment Sequence is linked to this activity.
learning_activities.topic_description: Interprofessional workshop Students will participate in one (1) interprofessional workshop with Social Work students. This workshop will be held on campus and will not be recorded. Attendance is highly encouraged as Component 3 in the Holistic Assessment Sequence is linked to this activity.

learning_activities.topic:
Fluency Practical

In Week 9, students will participate in a paediatric fluency practical session in place of their regular tutorial. This session will use inquiry-based learning and small group discussions to deepen understanding of early speech pathology management for fluency/stuttering difficulties in children under five years old.

To make the most of this session, students must complete the online self-paced learning module and related preparation activities beforehand. As this is a small-group, interactive activity, it will not be recorded.
learning_activities.topic_description: Fluency Practical In Week 9, students will participate in a paediatric fluency practical session in place of their regular tutorial. This session will use inquiry-based learning and small group discussions to deepen understanding of early speech pathology management for fluency/stuttering difficulties in children under five years old. To make the most of this session, students must complete the online self-paced learning module and related preparation activities beforehand. As this is a small-group, interactive activity, it will not be recorded.

learning_activities.topic:
Paediatric Feeding Experience

On Friday in Week 11, students will participate in a 2-hour practical workshop focused on paediatric feeding, designed to support the development of skills in managing paediatric dysphagia. During the session, they will complete a series of part tasks (e.g., infant oral reflex examination, positioning, cue reading, and use of feeding equipment) and engage in a simulated interaction with the caregiver of a child experiencing feeding difficulties.
learning_activities.topic_description: Paediatric Feeding Experience On Friday in Week 11, students will participate in a 2-hour practical workshop focused on paediatric feeding, designed to support the development of skills in managing paediatric dysphagia. During the session, they will complete a series of part tasks (e.g., infant oral reflex examination, positioning, cue reading, and use of feeding equipment) and engage in a simulated interaction with the caregiver of a child experiencing feeding difficulties.

learning_activities.topic:
Supporting neurodivergent children and families workshop

In Week 11, Autism Queensland will deliver a workshop focused on supporting the communication needs of neurodivergent children and their families. The session will provide practical strategies and insights to enhance inclusive and effective communication across clinical and educational settings.

Note. This workshop is scheduled on a Friday and will replace the weekly tutorial.
learning_activities.topic_description: Supporting neurodivergent children and families workshop In Week 11, Autism Queensland will deliver a workshop focused on supporting the communication needs of neurodivergent children and their families. The session will provide practical strategies and insights to enhance inclusive and effective communication across clinical and educational settings. Note. This workshop is scheduled on a Friday and will replace the weekly tutorial.

learning_activities.topic:
Final lecture

The final lecture (Week 13) will review the course as a whole and discuss end of semester assessment.
learning_activities.topic_description: Final lecture The final lecture (Week 13) will review the course as a whole and discuss end of semester assessment.
